messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] school lunch stinx!
messages.msgSnippet: When my son was in ps Kindergarten, he was given detention 6 times for talking at lunch. He never stayed after, I wouldnt allow my 5 year old to be punnished
messages.messageBody:
When my son was in ps Kindergarten, he was given
detention 6 times for talking at lunch. He never
stayed after, I wouldnt allow my 5 year old to be
punnished like that, but I saw alot of kids in
detention for tiny infractions- running, talking, etc.
Kerry

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: Riding the school bus/was unschooling  lots of b...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/8/01 4:35:23 PM Pacific Standard Time, ecsamhill@earthlink.net writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/8/01 4:35:23 PM Pacific Standard Time,
ecsamhill@... writes:

<< I may have mis-read what I read online, but I think I've heard tell of
schools where silence is the normal lunchroom policy, not just a sometimes
thing. While I may have one tiny smidge of sympathy for the lunch ladies,
I still think it sound awful. >>


I doubt if you misread it. It's similar, in my mind, to the eliminatrion of
recess and even PE. The need to have this complete control over the behavior
of the kids, all in the name of education? competition? reducing stress on
staff?

candice

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: Riding the school bus/was unschooling  lots of b...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/8/01 5:35:12 PM, ecsamhill@earthlink.net writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/8/01 5:35:12 PM, ecsamhill@... writes:

<< I may have mis-read what I read online, but I think I've heard tell of
schools where silence is the normal lunchroom policy, not just a sometimes
thing. >>

I have seen that as a policy in a school I visited. Elementary---eat in
silence, wait for the others at your table to be through, all dismissed in
batches to go play. Yuck.

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: Riding the school bus/was unschooling  lots of b...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/8/01 8:46:50 AM Pacific Standard Time, ecsamhill@earthlink.net writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/8/01 8:46:50 AM Pacific Standard Time,
ecsamhill@... writes:

<< I know that sounds awful, but it could be worse. I've read (online) of
schools that make the children be silent at lunch time. Unbelievable!!! >>

Read online? It happened at my daughter's school as well as the school I
briefly taught at (although at that second school it was rarely enforceable).
It was a punishment for previous rowdy days. When I was in elementary school,
many years ago, we had a stop light on the cafeteria wall. Green = talk in
normal voices. Yellow = whisper. Red = silence.

Funny thing was, I loved it!

candice

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: Riding the school bus/was unschooling  lots of b...
messages.msgSnippet: ... enforceable). ... I may have mis-read what I read online, but I think I ve heard tell of schools where silence is the normal lunchroom policy, not just a
messages.messageBody:
>Read online? It happened at my daughter's school as well as the school I
>briefly taught at (although at that second school it was rarely
enforceable).
>It was a punishment for previous rowdy days.

I may have mis-read what I read online, but I think I've heard tell of
schools where silence is the normal lunchroom policy, not just a sometimes
thing. While I may have one tiny smidge of sympathy for the lunch ladies,
I still think it sound awful.

Betsy
